title: Wadjmose
text:
Wadjmose was an <a href="ancient%20Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>ian prince of the <a href="Eighteenth%20Dynasty%20of%20Egypt">18th Dynasty</a>; a son of Pharaoh <a href="Thutmose%20I">Thutmose I</a>.
Biography.
He is likely to have been born a few years before his father ascended the throne. He had a brother named <a href="Amenmose%20%28prince%29">Amenmose</a>; it is disputed who their mother was. If they were born to Queen <a href="Ahmose%20%28queen%29">Ahmose</a>, they were full brothers of <a href="Hatshepsut">Hatshepsut</a> and <a href="Nefrubity">Nefrubity</a>. On the other hand, Wadjmose may have been the son of Queen Mutnofret and thus a full brother of <a href="Thutmose%20II">Thutmose II</a>.
Wadjmose is depicted in the <a href="El%20Kab">El Kab</a> tomb of himself and Amenmose's tutor , as sitting on Paheri's lap. He is thought to have predeceased his father. Wadjmose and another prince named Ramose were mentioned in the Theban funerary chapel of <a href="Thutmose%20I">Thutmose I</a> where Queen <a href="Mutnofret">Mutnofret</a> is also included. This chapel may have been erected during the reign of Thutmose II between the places where later the mortuary temple of <a href="Thutmose%20IV">Thutmose IV</a> and the <a href="Ramesseum">Ramesseum</a> were built. A statue of Mutnofret was found here, making it likely that she was his mother.
Wadjmose's name occurs written in a <a href="cartouche">cartouche</a>, which is quite rare for princes.
